questions.text: A 6-year-old female child presented with non-blanchable, palpable petechial rash on lower limbs and buttocks, along with 3+ urinary protein and joint pains in knee and ankle. There was a preceding sore throat 2 weeks back, which was conservatively managed. What is the therapy of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation is classic for Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP / IgA Vasculitis):

  • Key features:
    • Palpable purpura (non-blanchable) on dependent areas (buttocks, legs)
    • Hematuria with proteinuria (nephritic pattern)
    • Joint involvement (knees, ankles)
    • History of URTI (2 weeks prior)

Pathogenesis & pathology:

  • Small vessel leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA deposition in dermal vessels and glomeruli.
  • Complement levels (C3) are normal.

Treatment:

  • Supportive/conservative care is the mainstay because:
    • 90% of cases resolve spontaneously within 4 weeks.
    • Steroids are reserved for severe GI involvement (bleeding, intussusception) or severe nephritis.
    • IVIG and plasmapheresis have no role in routine management.

Why not PSGN?

Though there is a history of sore throat, the combination of purpuric rash, joint pain, and normal complement levels strongly favors HSP over post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Key differences between HSP and PSGN:

Explanation of other options:

Steroids (Option B): Steroids are indicated in HSP only when there is severe GI involvement (severe abdominal pain, GI bleeding, intussusception) or severe renal disease (nephrotic syndrome, crescentic GN). They help reduce inflammation and shorten the duration of severe symptoms, but do not change the long-term prognosis.

IVIG (Option C): IVIG is used in immune-mediated diseases like Kawasaki disease or Guillain-Barré syndrome. It has no established role in HSP because the pathogenesis is IgA immune complex deposition, which does not respond to IVIG therapy.

Plasmapheresis (Option D): Plasmapheresis is useful in fulminant immune complex-mediated conditions such as Goodpasture's syndrome or ANCA-associated vasculitis with pulmonary-renal syndrome. It is not part of routine therapy in HSP and is reserved only for very rare, severe cases with rapidly progressive renal failure.

questions.text: All are seen in Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel, leukocytoclastic vasculitis characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura (most commonly on buttocks and lower limbs)
  • Abdominal pain
  • Arthritis or arthralgia
  • Renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria, IgA nephropathy)

Importantly, platelet counts are normal in HSP. This distinguishes it from other purpuric conditions like ITP.

Explanation of other options:

Glomerulonephritis (Option A): Renal involvement in HSP typically presents as hematuria and mild proteinuria due to IgA deposition in the glomeruli (similar to IgA nephropathy). It can occasionally progress to nephritic or nephrotic syndrome but usually resolves in children.

Abdominal Pain (Option B): Occurs due to vasculitis of mesenteric vessels, leading to colicky abdominal pain, sometimes with vomiting or GI bleeding. This pain usually occurs within days of the rash and is one of the diagnostic criteria for HSP.

Palpable purpura (Option D): The hallmark lesion of HSP-;non-blanchable, raised purpura that appears mainly on dependent areas (buttocks and lower limbs). Unlike thrombocytopenic purpura, these lesions occur with a normal platelet count.

questions.text: Risk of chronic renal disease in HSP?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The risk of chronic renal disease in Henoch–Schönlein Purpura (HSP / IgA Vasculitis) is low, but not zero:

  • Nelson (21st ed.):
    • 1-2% of children with HSP may develop chronic renal impairment.
  • OP Ghai (10th ed.):
    • States the risk as 1-5%.

Most cases:

  • Renal involvement (hematuria ± proteinuria) is transient and recovers within weeks to months.
  • Only a small proportion progress to long-term kidney disease, especially in cases with severe nephritis at onset.

questions.text: The indication to use prednisolone in Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HSP (IgA vasculitis):

  • A self-limited small-vessel vasculitis presenting with palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), arthralgia, abdominal pain, and renal involvement (hematuria ± proteinuria).
  • It usually follows an upper respiratory tract infection.

Role of Corticosteroids

  • Indication:
    • Corticosteroids are not given routinely.
    • They are used in severe systemic manifestations, particularly:
      • Severe GI involvement (persistent abdominal pain, GI bleeding, intussusception risk)
      • Life-threatening complications (e.g., orchitis, CNS involvement, pulmonary hemorrhage).
  • Effect:
    • Relieves abdominal and joint pain
    • Does NOT prevent nephritis or alter the long-term renal outcome.
  • Regimen:
    • Glucocorticoids such as oral prednisone (1-2 mg/kg/day), or in severe cases, intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone for 1-2 weeks followed by taper, reduce abdominal and joint pain but do not alter overall prognosis.

Explanation of other options:

Prevention of nephritis (Option A): Steroids do not prevent or modify renal disease in HSP.

Dependent purpuric rash (Option C): Skin lesions alone are treated supportively.

CNS dysfunction (Option D): CNS involvement (e.g., seizures, encephalopathy) is an indication for steroids, but the question asks for the primary/general indication, which is severe GI involvement.

questions.text: Peak age for Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP), also called IgA vasculitis, is the most common childhood vasculitis.

Epidemiology:

  • Worldwide distribution: Affects all ethnic groups.
  • Incidence: 14-20 per 100,000 children per year.
  • Age: Approximately 90% of cases occur in children between 3 and 10 years (peak: 4-8 years).
  • Sex ratio: More common in males (1.2-1.8 1).
  • Adults: Less common but associated with more severe and chronic complications.
  • Seasonal pattern: More frequent in winter and spring, uncommon in summer.
  • Trigger: Often follows an upper respiratory infection.

questions.text: What is the peak age for Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kawasaki Disease (KD) is an acute, self-limited medium-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects young children.
  • Age Distribution:
    • >80% of cases occur in children <5 years.
    • Peak incidence: 18-24 months.
    • It is rare below 3 months of age and is almost never seen in adults
  • Epidemiology:
    • More common in Asian populations (Japan, Korea, India).
    • Males are more commonly affected.

questions.text: All of the following features can be present in Kawasaki's disease except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Axillary lymphadenopathy is not a feature of Kawasaki disease; lymph node involvement is characteristically cervical, usually unilateral, and >1.5 cm.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome that primarily affects children. The disease has a biphasic course:

Acute Phase (first 1-2 weeks):

  • High-grade fever (>5 days)
  • Bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis
  • Oral mucosal changes: strawberry tongue, red, cracked lips
  • Polymorphous truncal rash
  • Redness/edema of hands and feet
  • Unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Marked irritability

Subacute Phase (weeks 2-4):

  • Desquamation/peeling of the skin on fingers and toes
  • Thrombocytosis (lab finding)
  • Risk of coronary artery aneurysms
  • Arthralgia or arthritis (large joints)

The classic diagnostic criteria (need ≥5 days of fever + 4 out of 5) include:

  1. Bilateral non-purulent bulbar conjunctivitis
  2. Oral changes - strawberry tongue, red cracked lips
  3. Polymorphous rash (primarily truncal)
  4. Extremity changes indurative edema of hands/feet in acute stage, periungual desquamation in subacute stage
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy (>1.5 cm, usually unilateral)

questions.text: Which among the following pediatric conditions is associated with mutations in the ITPKC gene as well as anti-endothelial cell antibody positivity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kawasaki disease is an acute, self-limited vasculitis of medium-sized arteries predominantly affecting children.

  • It is more common in young children (peak: 18-24 months) and in Japanese populations, with a male predominance.
  • Genetics: Mutations in the ITPKC gene and CASP-3 have been associated with increased susceptibility and severity.
  • Pathogenesis: A T-cell-mediated immune response with cytokine release leads to vascular injury.
  • Anti-endothelial cell antibodies are often found in patients and contribute to vascular inflammation, although they are not the primary cause.

Key clinical concern:

  • The main risk is coronary artery aneurysm formation during the subacute phase.

Explanation of other options:

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) (Option A): IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis, not linked with ITPKC mutations.

Systemic-onset JIA (Option C): Autoinflammatory, with IL-1/IL-6 pathway involvement.

Childhood SLE (Option D): Autoimmune with multiple autoantibodies, but no ITPKC mutation association.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in a child with Kawasaki Disease between the 3rd to 6th week of illness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thrombosis of CAA:

  • Timing: Between the 3rd and 6th week of Kawasaki Disease (KD), the most serious risk is the formation of coronary artery aneurysms (CAA).
  • Mechanism: These aneurysms predispose to thrombus formation and subsequent myocardial infarction, leading to sudden death.
  • Incidence:
    • Untreated KD → 20-25% develop CAA
    • IVIG-resistant KD → ~15%
    • Adequately treated KD → <5%

Explanation of other options:

Myocarditis (Option A): Myocarditis occurs early (acute phase, 1st-2nd week) of KD. It causes symptoms such as tachycardia, heart failure, and mitral regurgitation. While it is the most common cardiac complication, fatalities due to myocarditis are rare after the second week because treatment (IVIG, aspirin) reduces inflammation.

KD Shock Syndrome (Option B): This is a rare complication seen during the acute phase (early illness). It is due to profound inflammation leading to capillary leak, myocardial dysfunction, and hypotension. Though severe, it usually occurs early and not in the 3rd-;6th week.

CCF due to Mitral Regurgitation (MR) (Option D): Caused by valvulitis and myocarditis in early KD. Heart failure related to MR is seen in the acute phase, not typically responsible for deaths weeks after onset unless severe myocarditis persists.

questions.text: Not a feature of Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Conjunctivitis in KD is always non-purulent.
  • Purulent discharge suggests an infectious etiology (e.g., bacterial conjunctivitis), not KD.

Kawasaki disease (KD), also called mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome, is a medium-vessel vasculitis most common in children <5 years.

Key diagnostic features of Kawasaki disease:

  • Fever: Persistent for ≥ 5 days (Option A ruled out)
  • Changes in extremities:
    • Acute phase: Erythema and edema of hands and feet
    • Subacute phase: Periungual peeling (weeks 2-3) (Option D ruled out)
  • Rash: Polymorphous exanthem, usually truncal (Option B ruled out)
  • Conjunctival injection: Bilateral, bulbar, non-purulent
  • Oral cavity changes: Cracked lips, strawberry tongue, diffuse mucosal erythema
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy: ≥1.5 cm, usually unilateral

Exclusion of other diseases with similar findings should be made.

  • KD is diagnosed if fever, along with 4 criteria, is present.
  • KD is called "Incomplete KD" if fever with only 2 or 3 criteria are present
  • KD is called "Atypical KD" if additional CNS or hepatobiliary involvement is prominently seen.

questions.text: A 3 1/2 year old child presented with high fever for one week, cervical lymphadenopathy, red eyes, few erythematous papules on the trunk and tongue, as shown in the picture. What is the most likely complication you will anticipate in the first 7-10 days of illness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation (prolonged high fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, non-exudative conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, and rash) is classic for Kawasaki Disease (KD).

Timeline of cardiac complications in KD:

  • Acute phase (Day 1-10):
    • Myocarditis is the most frequent complication.
    • Pathology: Diffuse inflammation of the myocardium, often subclinical, but may cause tachycardia, muffled heart sounds, or, rarely, congestive heart failure.
    • Pericardial effusion and valvulitis may also be seen in this phase.
  • Subacute phase (Week 2-3):
    • Formation of coronary artery aneurysms (CAA) is the most dreaded complication.
    • CAA is the most common cause of death overall, but it occurs later than the acute phase.
    • CAA incidence: 15-25% in untreated KD; 3-5% in IVIG-treated KD.
  • Convalescent phase (>6 weeks):
    • Healing of vessels and regression or persistence of aneurysms.

Explanation of other options:

Coronary artery aneurysm (Option A): Occurs later (2-3 weeks), not within the first 7-10 days.

Toxic shock syndrome (Option C): Presents with rapid shock and multiorgan involvement, not a complication of KD.

Pericardial effusion (Option D): Can occur, but is much less frequent than myocarditis in the early phase.

questions.text: "White strawberry tongue" is seen in a febrile child, as shown in the picture. What can be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Scarlet Fever (caused by Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus):
    • Early phase (first 1-2 days): The tongue is coated white with red, hypertrophied papillae protruding through → White Strawberry Tongue.
    • Later phase (after 2-3 days): The white coating peels off → Red Strawberry Tongue.
  • This is a classic, high-yield sign for Scarlet Fever.

Explanation of other options:

Late Kawasaki disease (Option B): Kawasaki disease also has a strawberry tongue, but during the first few days, it may appear "white strawberry" and later become "red strawberry". However, the typical exam association is Scarlet Fever, unless other KD features are described (conjunctivitis, rash, extremity changes).

Can be seen in both (Option C): Factually correct, as white strawberry tongue occurs in both Scarlet Fever and early Kawasaki. But without other KD findings, Scarlet Fever is preferred as the single best answer.

Normal variant (Option D): Incorrect. Strawberry tongue is always a pathological finding.

choices.text: Associated with coronary artery aneurysm in up to 25% of untreated cases
It is the most common cause of vasculitis in children
IV immunoglobulin is recommended only if the coronary artery is involved
Lymph node biopsy is used for diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Kawasaki disease is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kawasaki disease (KD) is a medium-vessel vasculitis.
  • Coronary artery aneurysms (CAA):
    • Without treatment, it develops in 20-25% of cases (highest risk between the 2nd-3rd week).
    • With timely IVIG therapy, reduced to <5%.
  • KD is diagnosed clinically (no single diagnostic test), and early IVIG (within 10 days) is recommended in all cases, not just those with coronary involvement, to prevent CAA.

Explanation of other options:

It is the most common cause of vasculitis in children (Option B): Incorrect. Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (IgA vasculitis) is the most common vasculitis in children. KD is the second most common.

IV immunoglobulin is recommended only if the coronary artery is involved (Option C): Incorrect. IVIG is given to all patients (ideally within 7-10 days of onset) because it prevents coronary complications. It is not limited to patients with existing coronary lesions.

Lymph node biopsy is used for diagnosis (Option D): Incorrect. Diagnosis is clinical, based on fever ≥5 days plus ≥4 out of 5 principal features (conjunctivitis, mucosal changes, rash, extremity changes, lymphadenopathy). Lymph node biopsy has no role.

choices.text: Repeat dose of IVIG followed by steroids will be needed
A double dose of IVIG and aspirin is indicated
Cyclophosphamide is the next line of management
The risk of coronary artery aneurysm is decreased by IVIG even if fever persists

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was clinically diagnosed with Kawasaki disease and started on IVIG infusion, which was given in a dose of 2 g/kg and completed over 10 hours. He was also given aspirin in a dose of 80 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses. More than 48 hours later, the child continues to have high-grade fever. Which among the following is true regarding this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

IVIG-Resistant Kawasaki Disease (KD):

  • If a child continues to have fever ≥36 hours after completing the first IVIG infusion (2 g/kg), the disease is classified as IVIG-resistant KD.
  • These children are at increased risk for developing coronary artery aneurysms (CAAs).

Next line of management:

  • The second dose of IVIG (2 g/kg) is recommended first.
  • If fever persists after the second dose, corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone pulse followed by taper) or biologic agents such as infliximab are considered.

Aspirin:
The aspirin dose is not increased. It is continued at anti-inflammatory doses until the child is afebrile, then switched to antiplatelet doses.

Risk of CAAs:
Persistent fever increases the risk of CAA, even though IVIG has been started. Hence, further treatment is necessary to control inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

A double dose of IVIG and aspirin is indicated (Option B): Incorrect. The IVIG dose remains 2 g/kg; it is not doubled. The aspirin dose is not increased beyond standard anti-inflammatory levels.

Cyclophosphamide is the next line of management (Option C): Incorrect. Cyclophosphamide is not used in KD management.

Risk of coronary artery aneurysm is decreased by IVIG even if fever persists (Option D): Incorrect. Persistent fever after IVIG indicates ongoing inflammation and increased risk of aneurysm.

questions.text: All of the following are consistent with the cardiac complications described in Kawasaki Disease, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Small effusions are possible, but clinically significant tamponade is extremely rare in Kawasaki Disease. Therefore, cardiac tamponade is NOT a typical complication.

Cardiac involvement is the most significant complication of Kawasaki Disease:

  • Myocarditis (Option A ruled out)
    • Seen in most patients during the acute phase.
    • Presents as tachycardia disproportionate to fever and decreased left ventricular systolic function.
  • KD Shock Syndrome (KDSS) (Option B ruled out)
    • Some patients present with cardiogenic shock due to severe myocardial dysfunction.
    • These patients are at higher risk of coronary artery dilatation.
  • Mitral Regurgitation (Option C ruled out)
    • Mild MR is found in 10-25% of patients at presentation (on echo).
    • Usually improves over time unless there are complications like coronary aneurysms or ischemia.
  • Coronary Artery Aneurysms (CAA)
    • The most dreaded complication.
    • Develop in 20-25% of untreated children, usually in the 2nd-3rd week.

questions.text: A child with Kawasaki Disease underwent echocardiography and was found to have a giant aneurysm on the Right Coronary Artery, for which he was hospitalized and managed. Which among the following is a cut-off to define a giant coronary artery aneurysm in a Kawasaki Disease patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In KD Patients, large or giant coronary artery aneurysms are responsible for most of the morbidity and mortality.

  • Large or giant aneurysmshave been defined by the 2017 American Heart Association (AHA) as having a z-score≥10 or an absolute dimension of ≥8 mm.
  • Japanese Classification of Aneurysms in KD
    • Small:≤4 mm internal diameter [ID])
    • Medium(>4 to ≤8 mm ID)
    • Giant(>8 mm ID).
  • Specifically, large or giant aneurysms are associated with the greatest risk of thrombosis or stenosis, angina, and myocardial infarction.
  • Rupture of a giant aneurysm is a rare complication that generally occurs in the 1st months after illness onset and may present as hemopericardium with tamponade.
  • Axillary, popliteal, iliac, or other arteries may also become aneurysmal, but always in the setting of giant coronary aneurysms.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with high-grade fever, desquamating rash on the body, lymphadenopathy, conjunctivitis, and Strawberry tongue in the mouth. Which among the following can be used to clinically distinguish Kawasaki Disease from Scarlet Fever?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both Kawasaki Disease (KD) and Scarlet Fever can present with:

  • High-grade fever
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Generalized rash (desquamating in later stages)
  • Lymphadenopathy

Key distinguishing feature:

  • Scarlet Fever:
    • Fever rapidly subsides within 24-48 hours of starting appropriate beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillin).
  • Kawasaki Disease:
    • Fever persists despite antibiotics, lasting 5 days or more.

questions.text: Which among the following is the drug of choice in patients with KD?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Drug of choice (DOC): Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG)

  • Dose: 2 g/kg as a single infusion over 10-12 hours.
  • Timing: Should be given within the first 10 days of illness, ideally as soon as the diagnosis is made.
  • Effect: Significantly reduces the risk of coronary artery aneurysms from ~25% to <5%.

Role of Aspirin:

  • Used in addition to IVIG.
  • High-dose aspirin (30-50 mg/kg/day divided q6h) during acute febrile phase → switch to low-dose (3-5 mg/kg/day) once afebrile for antiplatelet effect.

Other drugs (prednisolone, infliximab):

  • Used only in IVIG-resistant cases or severe complications (e.g., persistent fever despite IVIG).

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspirin (Option A): Aspirin is an adjunct therapy in KD but not the primary drug of choice. It helps with inflammation and prevents thrombosis, but does not reduce the risk of coronary aneurysms as effectively as IVIG.

Prednisolone (Option B): Corticosteroids may be used only in refractory KD (when fever persists despite IVIG) or in high-risk cases but are not first-line.

Infliximab (Option C): TNF-α inhibitors like infliximab can be used in IVIG-resistant KD, but not as primary therapy.

questions.text: Which among the following is effective in systemic onset JIA (SoJIA)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Systemic-Onset Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (SoJIA):

  • SoJIA is classified as an autoinflammatory disease rather than autoimmune.
  • It is characterized by innate immune system activation with excessive production of IL1 and IL6.
  • Unlike other JIA subtypes, it is not driven by TNF-α or autoantibodies (ANA, RF negative).

Clinical Presentation:

  • Quotidian spiking fever: ≥2 weeks
  • Rash: Salmon-pink maculopapular rash (transient, appears with fever)
  • Systemic features: Generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, serositis (pleuritis, pericarditis)
  • Arthritis: May appear later or be initially absent
  • Lab: Markedly elevated ESR/CRP, leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, hyperferritinemia
  • Complication: Risk of Macrophage Activation Syndrome (MAS)

Treatment Rationale:

  1. First-line for systemic features:
  • Oral corticosteroids (e.g., Prednisone)
  • IV methylprednisolone in severe systemic disease (pericarditis, MAS)
  1. Biologic therapy (used early or if steroids are insufficient):
  • IL-1 inhibitors (Anakinra, Canakinumab)
  • IL-6 inhibitor (Tocilizumab)
  • These specifically block the cytokines central to SoJIA inflammation.
  1. Methotrexate:
  • Limited role; more useful once arthritis becomes predominant.

Why steroids are key initially:

  • Rapid control of fever, systemic inflammation, and prevention of life-threatening complications like MAS.
  • Later, biologics are introduced to minimize steroid exposure.

Explanation of other options:

NSAIDs (Option A): May relieve joint pain but are ineffective for systemic features. Nelson: NSAIDs are used only in very mild disease without systemic involvement.

Infliximab (Anti-TNF) (Option B): SoJIA is not TNF-α mediated. Anti-TNF agents are effective in polyarticular JIA, not in SoJIA.

Rituximab (Option C): Works by depleting B cells (CD20). Since SoJIA is cytokine-driven rather than autoantibody-driven, it has no therapeutic role.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a history of joint stiffening in the morning and feeling tired after school, with some joint pain in her lower limbs. On examination, her left knee is warm and swollen. Swelling and pain in joints are also found in 6 of her small joints of fingers. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 55, and C-reactive protein is 70 mg/l. The white cell count is normal, with a high platelet count. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key findings from the case:

  • Morning stiffness → suggests inflammatory arthritis
  • >5 joints involved (large + small joints) → polyarticular pattern
  • Lab findings: Elevated ESR/CRP, thrombocytosis (reactive), but normal WBC → typical of JIA
  • Age & gender: 12-year-old girl, which fits the peak age group for polyarticular JIA

The presentation is highly suggestive of Polyarticular-onset Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA).

This subtype accounts for approximately 20% of all JIA cases.

Key features of Polyarticular-onset JIA:

  1. Epidemiology
    • More common in females.
    • Typical onset is between 12 and 16 years of age.
  2. Joint involvement
    • Defined by arthritis affecting more than 5 joints within the first 6 months of the disease.
    • Symmetrical small-joint involvement is common, similar to adult rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Flexor tenosynovitis and rheumatoid nodules may be present.
  3. Rheumatoid factor (RF)
    • A subset is RF IgM-positive, which tends to mimic adult-onset RA in its pattern and prognosis.
    • RF-negative patients may have hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and symmetrical arthritis.
  4. Systemic features
    • Systemic features are less common in this form compared to systemic-onset JIA.
    • However, extra-articular manifestations can include lung, cardiac, aortic, and vascular involvement.
  5. Joints most commonly affected:
    • Hips, neck, hands, feet, knees, wrists, and ankles.
  6. Radiological findings
    • Soft tissue swelling is the earliest finding.
    • Erosions can appear as the disease progresses
  7. Prognosis
    • Active disease in adulthood is more common in polyarticular JIA, especially in RF-positive patients.
    • Systemic involvement is more characteristic of systemic and oligoarticular JIA, not polyarticular JIA.

Explanation of other options:

Systemic-onset JIA (Option A): Systemic JIA (Still's disease) usually presents with quotidian fever, salmon-pink rash, hepatosplenomegaly, serositis - none of these are seen here. The main problem in this case is joint involvement without systemic features.

Behçet's disease (Option C): Behçet's disease presents with oral/genital ulcers, uveitis, vasculitis, and not isolated arthritis.

Scleroderma (Option D): Scleroderma presents with skin tightening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and limited joint involvement, not polyarthritis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with a fever for 2 weeks and loss of appetite. He is miserable, complaining of pain in his neck, and has not been able to walk for the last 3 days. The joints in his legs are all swollen and hot, and he has neck stiffness. The spleen is 3 cm. He had a pink, slightly itchy rash on the trunk, which faded in 1 week. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presentation in this 2-year-old boy-prolonged fever, loss of appetite, irritability, inability to walk, multiple swollen joints, splenomegaly, neck stiffness, and a transient salmon-pink rash-is classic for Systemic-onset Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (SoJIA), previously called Still's disease.

Key Features of Systemic JIA:

  1. Fever Pattern
    • High spiking fevers (≥39.5°C) typically occur late in the afternoon or evening.
    • Fever returns to normal or below normal by morning (quotidian fever pattern).
    • Often, the first and most striking symptom.
  2. Characteristic Rash
    • Salmon-pink, evanescent (comes and goes) macular or slightly itchy rash.
    • Usually on the trunk and thighs.
    • Appears with fever spikes and fades as the fever subsides.
  3. Systemic Features
    • Generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and serositis (pericarditis, myocarditis, pleuritis).
    • Neck stiffness may be due to severe systemic inflammation.
  4. Arthritis
    • Occurs in ~75% of cases but may appear after the fever starts.
    • Commonly affects wrists, knees, and ankles, and can also involve hands and temporomandibular joints.
    • The polyarthritis pattern (many joints involved) is typical.
  5. Course and Prognosis
    • The disease usually lasts 2-5 years before remitting, but it can cause significant morbidity.
    • Risk of macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) as a severe complication.

Additional Points from the Case:

  • Splenomegaly: Seen in up to 75% of SoJIA patients.
  • Irritable and miserable child: Typical of SoJIA due to persistent systemic inflammation.
  • Rash disappeared after 1 week: Matches the evanescent nature of the SoJIA rash.

Explanation of other options:

Oligoarticular JIA (Option A): Involves ≤4 joints in the first 6 months. Systemic symptoms (fever, rash, splenomegaly) are not prominent.

Sjögren's Syndrome (Option B): Rare in children, presents with dry eyes and mouth, not fever, with arthritis.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (Option D): Presents in older children/adolescents, with sacroiliac and spinal pain. Does not cause fever, rash, or hepatosplenomegaly.

choices.text: Rheumatoid factor is an important diagnostic test to perform in suspected cases
Methotrexate is the first-line drug in therapy

questions.text: The true statement about Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) is a group of autoimmune arthritides affecting children under 16 years of age, lasting for at least 6 weeks.

  • Oligoarticular JIA (formerly called pauciarticular) is the most common subtype.
  • It accounts for 40-60% of all JIA cases.
  • Defined as 4 or fewer joints involved in the first 6 months, commonly affecting large joints (knees, ankles).
  • ANA positivity is common and increases the risk of chronic anterior uveitis.

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid factor is an important diagnostic test (Option A): RF is positive in <10% of JIA cases and is not a key diagnostic criterion. ANA (antinuclear antibody) is more relevant, especially for oligoarticular JIA (risk of uveitis). JIA remains a clinical diagnosis.

Cervical spine involvement is uncommon (Option C): Cervical spine involvement is quite common, occurring in up to 50% of cases, particularly in polyarticular JIA, leading to limited neck mobility and atlantoaxial subluxation.

Methotrexate is the first-line drug (Option D): First-line therapy is NSAIDs for initial symptom control. Methotrexate is introduced for persistent or polyarticular disease not controlled by NSAIDs. Biologics are reserved for refractory cases.

questions.text: The most common bony finding on a skeletal radiograph in JIA is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Despite the significant inflammation present in Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), plain radiographs are relatively insensitive in detecting bony changes during the early stages of the disease.
  • The most common finding is a normal radiograph of the bone and joint.
  • When changes do appear, the earliest is periarticular osteopenia, but it is important to note that this finding only becomes visible after more than 50% of the bone mineral content has been lost due to inflammation.
  • Later findings in long-standing or severe cases include:
    • Joint space narrowing due to cartilage loss
    • Periosteal new bone formation
    • And most ominously, bony erosions, which indicate irreversible joint damage.

Explanation of other options:

Periarticular osteopenia (Option B): Periarticular osteopenia is an early radiographic sign of chronic synovitis, caused by increased blood flow and inflammatory cytokines leading to localized bone demineralization. However, it only becomes visible when over 50% of bone mineral is lost, so it is not the most common finding early in JIA.

Joint space narrowing (Option C): Joint space narrowing occurs later in the course of JIA due to destruction of articular cartilage from chronic inflammation. This is a progressive and irreversible change and is not typically seen in the early phases.

Periosteal new bone formation (Option D): This occurs as a late finding in JIA when there is chronic inflammation, especially in more severe or long-standing disease. It reflects reactive bone deposition along the cortex and usually appears after other early changes have already developed.

choices.text: Malar rash with chest pain: systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.text: The following symptoms may be suggestive of rheumatic disease, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA)

  • Key symptoms: Joint swelling, stiffness, and pain.
  • True muscle weakness is not a feature of JIA. Any reduced activity is due to joint pain and stiffness rather than primary muscle involvement.
  • Pathology: Autoimmune inflammation confined to the synovium.
  • Muscle weakness occurs in inflammatory myopathies, not JIA.

Explanation of other options

Fever: systemic juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (Option A): High spiking fevers are a classic feature of systemic-onset JIA. Accompanied by an evanescent rash, hepatosplenomegaly, and serositis.

Arthralgia: dermatomyositis (Option B): Joint pain (arthralgia) can occur in dermatomyositis, although the hallmark is muscle weakness. Arthralgias may coexist due to systemic inflammation.

Malar rash with chest pain: systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D): Butterfly rash (malar rash) is typical of SLE. Chest pain often results from serositis (pericarditis/pleuritis), which is common in SLE.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents with difficulty in combing, climbing stairs, and skin lesions as shown. Gower Sign is positive. What shall be the next step in diagnostic work-up?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic triad in this child-proximal muscle weakness (difficulty combing/climbing), Gower sign, and Gottron's papules (erythematous lesions over MCP joints)-is highly suggestive of Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM).
According to the 2017 EULAR/ACR classification criteria for idiopathic inflammatory myopathies, once characteristic skin signs and proximal weakness are present, measurement of serum muscle enzymes (particularly CK) is the first diagnostic step.

Key Diagnostic Features of JDM (2017 EULAR/ACR criteria):

  1. Symmetrical proximal muscle weakness
  2. Typical rashes:
    • Gottron papules: Raised, violaceous papules on MCP/PIP joints
    • Heliotrope rash: Lilac discoloration of eyelids with edema
    • Gottron sign: Flat erythema over extensor joints (elbows, knees)
  3. V-sign (photo rash over chest) & Shawl sign (upper back/shoulders)
  4. Elevated muscle enzymes (CK, LDH, AST, ALT, aldolase)
  5. EMG or biopsy (if diagnosis uncertain)

A score ≥7.5 without biopsy, or ≥8.7 with biopsy, confirms inflammatory myopathy.

Associations and Complications of JDM

  • Calcinosis cutis (late complication)
  • Lipodystrophy
  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Cardiac: Myocarditis, conduction abnormalities
  • GI vasculitis: Ulceration, perforation (rare but serious)
  • Overlap syndromes with SLE/scleroderma

Explanation of other options:

Do RF levels (Option A): Not used for JDM; they are relevant for JIA and RA.

Do EMG (Option B): Invasive and used only when the diagnosis is unclear after clinical and enzyme evaluation.

Do Nerve conduction studies (Option C): Assess peripheral nerve disorders, not primary muscle diseases.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with difficulty in going upstairs and leg pains. She is always tired, feels hot, and has had some weight loss. The family doctor has seen her on several occasions for erythematous papules on the dorsum of her hands. The muscle enzyme is 1500 mmol/l, and ESR is 90, with thrombocytosis. Lactate dehydrogenase is high, as is ANA. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This child's presentation is classic for Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM):

Key clues from the case:

  • Symptoms:
    • Difficulty climbing stairs and leg pains → proximal muscle weakness (girdle pattern).
    • Fatigue, weight loss, low-grade fever, → systemic inflammatory illness.
  • Skin findings:
    • Erythematous papules over the dorsum of hands → Gottron papules, pathognomonic for JDM.
  • Lab findings:
    • Very high muscle enzymes (CK, LDH, AST).
    • High ESR and thrombocytosis (markers of inflammation).
    • Positive ANA (seen in many autoimmune diseases but supports an inflammatory process).
  • Genetics:
    • JDM is strongly associated with HLA-DQA1*0501 in ~80% of cases.

Diagnosis:
Combination of Gottron papules, heliotrope rash (if present), proximal muscle weakness, and raised CK = Juvenile Dermatomyositis.

Explanation of other options:

Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) (Option A): JIA causes joint swelling and pain, not proximal muscle weakness. It does not cause Gottron papules or elevated muscle enzymes.

Behçet's disease (Option B): Characterized by oral/genital ulcers and uveitis, not muscle weakness or Gottrón papules.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option C): SLE can have fatigue, weight loss, ANA positivity, and rash, but does not cause marked proximal myopathy with very high CK. SLE rash (malar rash) differs from Gottron papules.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with back pain and pain in both ankles and the left knee. When he bends forward, his lower spine remains straight. There is localized tenderness around the left foot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 14-year-old boy presents with:

  • Back pain with reduced spinal flexion:
    • Key finding: On forward bending, the lower spine remains straight.
    • This loss of spinal flexibility is called a positive Schober's test and is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
  • Peripheral joint involvement:
    • Ankle and knee pain, along with localized tenderness at the foot, indicate enthesitis, which is a hallmark of spondyloarthropathies.
    • Enthesitis = inflammation at tendon/ligament insertion sites (e.g., Achilles tendon, plantar fascia).

Key Features of Ankylosing Spondylitis:

  1. Group:
    • Belongs to seronegative spondyloarthropathies (HLA-B27 positive, RF negative).
  2. Typical presentation:
  3. Adolescent male with:
    • Inflammatory back pain (improves with exercise, not rest).
      • Reduced forward flexion (positive Schober's test).
      • Oligoarthritis of lower limbs (hips, knees, ankles).
      • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia).
  4. Investigations:
    • HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of juvenile AS cases.
    • ESR: Often elevated.
    • X-ray: Sacroiliitis with extensive sclerosis, erosions of joint margins, and apparent widening of the sacroiliac joint space.
  5. Complications:
    • Iridocyclitis (acute anterior uveitis) occurs in about 25% of cases.
  6. Treatment:
    • Focus on controlling pain and reducing inflammation with NSAIDs, physiotherapy, and biologics (if severe).

Explanation of other options:

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option B): SLE typically causes polyarthritis (small joints), rashes, oral ulcers, renal involvement, not axial spine involvement or enthesitis.

Postinfectious (Reactive) Arthritis (Option C): Can present with arthritis and enthesitis, but axial spine involvement (straight spine on forward bending)strongly favors AS. Also, postinfectious arthritis often follows a recent infection (GI/GU), which is not mentioned here.

Polyarteritis Nodosa (Option D): PAN presents with medium vessel vasculitis (skin nodules, neuropathy, hypertension), not axial arthritis or enthesitis.
